Headline.Para: American inaction on gun control has deep roots

LeadPara.Para: The cowboy icon and distrust of government explain Americans' penchant for guns

Days after the Valentine's Day shooting that left 17 dead at a Florida secondary school, Minister for Home Affairs K. Shanmugam said in a Facebook post: "It baffles me that people are freely allowed to buy submachine guns in an urban environment."

TailParas.Para: American inaction against gun violence also baffles students in courses I teach at Nanyang Technological University. Why doesn't the American government just stop the carnage, they ask.

Only soldiers and police should be able to carry weapons, they argue. They support Singapore's 1973 law imposing the death penalty for arms trafficking or use of a firearm to commit an offence, and prison and caning for possession of unlicensed firearms.
Inaction on gun control sometimes baffles Americans, myself included.

Mr Shanmugam offered a partial explanation: "democracy American-style", in which "those who want free access to guns (though a minority) are better organised" and "channel money to congressmen" to "block any legislation that seeks to control people from buying assault rifles".
It takes more than money and organisation for special interest groups like the National Rifle Association to stall meaningful gun control, however.
The Second Amendment to the federal Constitution, along with deeply held American views about the role of guns, limit the American public's imagination about reforms.

The March For Our Lives events, organised by survivors of the Feb 14 Florida school shooting, call for legislative action to address gun violence. PHOTO: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

The Second Amendment, drafted in 1789, states in notoriously opaque words: "A well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed."

Its first clause refers to militias, the bands of civilian fighters, carrying their own arms, that each state assembled in the republic's early days. It also refers to "the people", and in 2008 the Supreme Court interpreted it as guaranteeing an individual right to bear arms for self-protection outside of military contexts.
Just as important as the role of the Constitution is the status of guns in the American psyche.

American movies of the "Western" genre provide a window on a mythologised vision of frontier life that underlies some Americans' views. A cowboy on the frontier needs a gun not only for hunting, but also for self-defence. He is self-reliant; he cannot just call the cops. He may use his gun to stand up to law enforcement that has turned rogue. Such an icon has few, if any, Singapore counterparts.

Few Americans today live in places reminiscent of frontier towns, but the perceived need for self-defence remains. Though violent crime has fallen from its peak in the 1990s, many Americans in urban areas believe they must be armed to protect their families.
About one-third of American households have at least one gun. In my childhood home in a small town in Wisconsin, our family of four had 11 guns.

My views on gun control were shaped by an afternoon when I was seven years old. My father took my sister and me to visit an uncle. Bored, I snooped in his drawers. In his nightstand I found his handgun. I held it and stared down the barrel, wondering what would happen if I pulled the trigger. That's when my father entered the bedroom and told me to put the gun down. I obeyed. The uncle never revealed whether the gun was loaded.

There is little evidence that a gun in the home makes it safer. Gun ownership is, however, associated with shootings of household members, whether homicide, suicide or accidents, according to the National Crime Victimisation Survey.
Many Americans know of cases. One of my high school classmates murdered his parents and brother; a gun was one of the weapons. In my home town, I knew of a teen who committed suicide with a gun.
Americans arm themselves against not only street crime, but also the possibility that the government might become the enemy, another idea with little resonance in contemporary Singapore.

In the British colonies that became the United States, the Patriots who advocated American independence believed that they must be able to repulse an invasion or take up arms against their own rulers, should they abuse power. Fearing revolt, the British embargoed arms to the colonies. Soldiers who won American independence on the battlefield were among those who later drafted the Second Amendment.

In the centuries since, American distrust in the authorities remains, in altered forms. A few right-wing radicals arm for battle, should government turn totalitarian. More common is distrust of the police, and for good reason, in some communities. Former secretary of state Condoleezza Rice recently recounted how, during her youth in 1950s Alabama, African Americans fired guns in the air to remind the Ku Klux Klan, and the local police who supported it, that they were armed.

Decades of allegations of racial profiling by law enforcement, inconsistent response to emergency calls from poor neighbourhoods, and documented police brutality reinforce beliefs that one needs to be armed to fend for oneself.

Ultimately, the difference between American and Singaporean on guns is rooted in differences in trust in the authorities. Singaporeans trust the police and Government to keep them safe, so ordinary citizens feel they don't need firearms.
Singapore's leaders make no apologies for strict gun regulation. They need not. Debate about guns is non-existent.
Singaporean law and order is as integral to the young nation's identity as America's radical approach to liberty is to its identity.

The Florida massacre renewed legislators' discussion of bans on assault rifles. A month has passed, and now that the planned demonstrations at high schools - in Washington and across the nation - are over, America is in a critical window of time where momentum builds or dwindles.

Banning individual gun ownership is not on the table. As presidential candidate for the Democratic Party, which tends to favour more gun controls than Republicans, Mrs Hillary Clinton took pains to remind voters of her support of the right to bear arms. Going further in a federal election is perceived as electoral suicide. Even some students who survived the Florida shooting have stated that they are not asking for repeal of the Second Amendment.

American idealisation of the revolutionary and the cowboy, along with modern distrust in the authorities to keep them safe, has narrowed options for reform, with tragic consequences. The generation of teenagers spurred to protest might do well to look to gun laws of Singapore, Australia and Britain.
Public support for fundamental change may take time, however. Until members of the public trust the government to keep them safe, the appeal of gun ownership may continue.
•Mark Cenite teaches at the Wee Kim Wee School of Communication & Information, where he is associate chair (academic).
